course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Cultures and Values: Love, Death and Human Nature
course.description: Three basic values will be explored in this course: Love, death and human nature. Lectures and readings will be built upon selected texts of Chinese philosophy and religion. For the concept of love, love as benevolence in Confucius’ and Mencius’ thoughts and love as universal love in Mohism will be compared and explored. For the concept of death, a naturalistic view of death in contrast to death viewed by Chinese Buddhism and religious Taoism will be introduced. A Confucian view of death will be put forward as a dialectical unity of the previous two seemingly contradictory views of death. As for the concept of human nature, various traditional views of human nature will be discussed and a suggestion is given to explain why Mencius’ idea that human nature is good triumphs over other views and becomes the orthodox view of human nature in the Chinese tradition.

reviews.author: Patricknely
reviews.title: A very educational course !
reviews.comment_content:
The course is dedicated to introducing some basic ancient Chinese doctrine regarding to Love, Death and Human Nature. The reading material come from many famous ancient Chinese philosophers, so it’s quite difficult for non-Chinese to understand the full meaning due to translation issue.

All reading PDFs are well prepared and the key points are well delivered. Each topic follows corresponding discussion, where students need to share their views and counterarguments timely and frequently to get a high grade.

There is a essay workshop attached to this class. Basically it teaches you to write each paragraph professionally. Very helpful. Each workshop session teaches you to write one paragraph, so you don’t need to work hard to finish your final essay before deadline.

Finally, the final essay provides you 3 topics concerning each topic that the course has discussed. You can choose your favorite topic to complete your essay.
**
Topic 1: Love
Mozi - On Universal Love
The Analects - On Love As Humanity
Mencius - On Love
Topic 2: Death
**The material under this topic is way too difficult to understand :( **
Wang Chung - A Treatise on Death
Fung Yu-lan - Contemporary Debate on the Immortality of the Soul
Pao-pu Tzu - The belief in Immortals
Zhuangzi - The Secret of Caring for Life
Liu Zhongzhou - Teaching on Life and Death
Topic 3: Human Nature
Xunzi  -  Man’s Nature is Evil
Han Yu - An Inquiry on Human Nature
Mencius - Human Nature is Good
reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.comment_workload:
1. 3 lecture quizzes/Multiple choice questions (20%)

2. Canvas online discussions (10%)
-  Peer exchange forum on questions and issues pertinent to lectures & weekly readings
- Three deadlines over the process of the discussion; topics given by each would be closed afterwards – see “Rubric for Canvas Peer Exchanges” for details

3. Online writing workshops (20%)
- Viewing online content and completion of all tasks embedded in the online content

4. Term essay (50%)
- Write a persuasive essay of 1000 words
-  Which is revised at least once
-  Show evidence of response to feedback on your first draft
